title: When in science a phenomenon is said to be 'random', what does that mean? Is randomness determined by analysis of observations? - Science and Math Geeks - Quora

response.answer_text: When, in science, a phenomenon is said to be "random", what does that mean? Is randomness determined by analysis of observations? Unlike mathematics, science is based on observations. When all initial conditions are accounted for, and repeated observations of a phenomenon show a variety of results which cannot be deterministic based upon the mathematical model chosen to predict the result, there are two choices: The phenomena is “random.”There are “hidden variables.”It is important to realize that “random” does not mean “statistically unpredictable.” For example, a radioactive atomic substance can have a determined half-life. But if you examine a single atom, you cannot predict when it will undergo spontaneous fission. Many quantum events are essentially random at the individual particle level. Even in classical science, experimental observations of phenomena based on continuous models are often subject to some amount of randomness. This is why scientists do not use Real numbers directly--scientific notation gives a numeric measurement two dimensions: precision and accuracy. When you did science experiments in school, you likely encountered some randomness on your measurements. This is part of the nature of the physical world, and many experiments get ever more precise and accurate results, but many mathematical models only have been observed to a limitted precision and accuracy, and what scientists find within yhe confidence level of measurement is random variation, when all known confounding factors are accounted for.

What is random? The most frequent description involves the expression “can’t predict.” For example, you cannot predict which light bulb on the assembly line will be defective. Or you can’t predict the next lotto numbers. This, we all accept. Another descriptor involves the expression “can’t explain.” For example, I can’t explain that tornado; it just appeared out of nowhere. Random? This type of randomness compels explanation. So, we make up theories, and often they are plausible. Another example is that global cooling occurred 50,000 years ago (last ice age). Again, no explanation but for unverifiable theories. We want to believe the theories because they give comfort. Yet, we know today’s theories are built upon the ruins of yesterday’s explanitons*. Yesterday’s randomness is explained by today’s theories. When it comes to tornados, volcanos, weather, and whatnot, the phenomenon of fractals, call it organized randomness, comes home - with a thud. *Explaniton – a particle of explanation for which the probability of truth is positive.

In mathematical terms of observational outcomes, random just means that every outcome is equally likely — the probability distribution of all possible outcomes is uniform. In scientific terms — proposing models that explain the causality of events and predicting their future occurrences — ‘random’ implies we know nothing about an event’s possible mechanisms and we cannot predict their recurrence. Each event is equally likely, no matter what the state of the likely mechanisms were or the state of the surrounding environmental conditions were just before the event of interest took place. In essence, the experts are mystified by something that just happened and can’t explain it.
